inlineContent.text: Typical uses are to display a message, ask a question, or anything else
that does not require extensive effort on the user’s part.
The main area of a
is called the “content area”, and is yours
to populate with widgets such a
or
, to present
your information, questions, or tasks to the user.
In addition, dialogs allow you to add “action widgets”. Most commonly,
action widgets are buttons. Depending on the platform, action widgets may
be presented in the header bar at the top of the window, or at the bottom
of the window. To add action widgets, create your
using
[ctor
], or use
[method
], [method
or [method
uses some heuristics to decide whether to add a close
button to the window decorations. If any of the action buttons use
the response ID
or
, the
close button is omitted.
Clicking a button that was added as an action widget will emit the
[signal
] signal with a response ID that you specified.
GTK will never assign a meaning to positive response IDs; these are
entirely user-defined. But for convenience, you can use the response
IDs in the [enum
] enumeration (these all have values
less than zero). If a dialog receives a delete event, the
[signal
] signal will be emitted with the
response ID.
Dialogs are created with a call to [ctor
] or
[ctor
]. The latter is recommended; it allows
you to set the dialog title, some convenient flags, and add buttons.
A “modal” dialog (that is, one which freezes the rest of the application
from user input), can be created by calling [method
on the dialog. When using [ctor
], you can also
pass the
flag to make a dialog modal.
For the simple dialog in the following example, a [class
would save some effort. But you’d need to create the dialog contents manually
if you had more than a simple message in the dialog.
An example for simple
usage:

code: // Function to open a dialog box with a message
// Ensure that the dialog box is destroyed when the user responds
// Add the label, and show everything we’ve added

inlineContent.text: The
implementation of the
interface exposes the
as an internal child with the name “content_area”.
supports a custom
element, which can contain
multiple
elements. The “response” attribute specifies a
numeric response, and the content of the element is the id of widget
(which should be a child of the dialogs
). To mark a response
as default, set the “default” attribute of the
element
to true.
supports adding action widgets by specifying “action” as
the “type” attribute of a
element. The widget will be added
either to the action area or the headerbar of the dialog, depending
on the “use-header-bar” property. The response id has to be associated
with the action widget using the
element.

type acts as a reference-counted owner of an underlying
instance.
It provides the methods that can operate on this data type through
conformance.

as a strong reference or owner of a

abstract.text: Convenience constructor to create a dialog with two buttons.
This creates a new GtkDialog with title
(or NULL for the default title; see gtk_window_set_title())
and transient parent parent.
The
argument can be used to make the dialog modal (GTK_DIALOG_MODAL)
and/or to have it destroyed along with its transient parent (GTK_DIALOG_DESTROY_WITH_PARENT).
After
, the button text and response ID pairs should be listed.
Each button text can be an arbitrary text.
If the user clicks the dialog button,
will emit the “response” signal
with the corresponding response ID.
If a GtkDialog receives the “delete-event” signal, it will emit ::response
with a response ID of
However, destroying a dialog does not emit the ::response signal;
so be careful relying on ::response when using the
flag.
Buttons are from left to right, so the first button in the list will be the leftmost button in the dialog.
allows objects to extend and customize their deserialization
from ui files.

is the interface implemented by all widgets that can act as a toplevel
widget.
